ZIP Code Lookup - Find a ZIP+ 4 Code By City Results | accessdate = 2007-01-18}} |area_code = [[Area code 310|310]]/[[Area code 424|424]]{{cite web | url = http://www.nanpa.com/nas/public/npa_city_query_step2.do?method=displayData&cityToNpaModel.stateAbbr=CA&cityToNpaModel.city=Carson | title = Number Administration System - NPA and City/Town Search Results | accessdate = 2007-01-18}} |website = [http://ci.carson.ca.us/ http://ci.carson.ca.us/] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = 06-11530{{GR|2}} |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 1660441{{GR|3}} |footnotes = }} '''Carson''' is a city in [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles County]], [[California]]. As of the 2010 census, Carson had a total population of 91,714. Located {{convert|13|mi|km}} south of downtown [[Los Angeles]] and approximately 14 miles away from the [[Los Angeles International Airport]], it is known as a [[suburb]] of the city.http://www.hospitalsoup.com/listing/56686-clarion-los-angeles Incorporated on February 20, 1968, Carson is the youngest municipality in the [[South Bay, Los Angeles|South Bay]] region of [[Greater Los Angeles area|Greater Los Angeles]]. == Geography == According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], Carson has a total area of {{convert|19.0|sqmi|km2}}. {{convert|18.7|sqmi|km2}} of it is land and {{convert|0.2|sqmi|km2}} of it (1.29%) is water. Carson is bordered by [[West Compton, California|West Compton]] on the north, [[Compton, California|Compton]] on the northeast, [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]] on the east, [[Wilmington, Los Angeles, California|Wilmington]] on the south, and [[West Carson, California|West Carson]] and [[Harbor Gateway, Los Angeles, California|Harbor Gateway]] on the west. == Demographics == {{USCensusPop | 1960=38059 | 1970=71150 | 1980=81221 | 1990=83995 | 2000=89730 | 2010=91714 | footnote=source:{{cite web |url=http://www.census.gov/prod/www/abs/decennial/index.html |title=CENSUS OF POPULATION AND HOUSING (1790-2000) |publisher=[[U.S. Census Bureau]] |accessdate=2010-07-30}}Census figure enumerated in 1960 was prior to incorporation. }} ===2010=== The [[2010 United States Census]]{{USCensus-2010CA}} reported that Carson had a population of 91,714. The [[population density]] was 4,835.2 people per square mile (1,866.9/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of Carson was 21,864 (23.8%) [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 21,856 (23.8%) [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 518 (0.6%) [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 23,522 (25.6%) [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 2,386 (2.6%) [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 17,151 (18.7%) from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 4,417 (4.8%) from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 35,417 persons (38.6%). The Census reported that 90,411 people (98.6% of the population) lived in households, 1,170 (1.3%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 133 (0.1%) were institutionalized. There were 25,432 households, out of which 10,980 (43.2%) had children under the age of 18 living in them, 14,178 (55.7%) were [[marriage|opposite-sex married couples]] living together, 4,787 (18.8%) had a female householder with no husband present, 1,761 (6.9%) had a male householder with no wife present. There were 990 (3.9%) [[POSSLQ|unmarried opposite-sex partnerships]], and 152 (0.6%) [[same-sex partnerships|same-sex married couples or partnerships]]. 3,776 households (14.8%) were made up of individuals and 1,790 (7.0%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.56. There were 20,726 [[family (U.S. Census)|families]] (81.5% of all households); the average family size was 3.90. The population was spread out with 21,992 people (24.0%) under the age of 18, 9,964 people (10.9%) aged 18 to 24, 23,105 people (25.2%) aged 25 to 44, 24,013 people (26.2%) aged 45 to 64, and 12,640 people (13.8%) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 37.6 years. For every 100 females there were 91.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 88.5 males. There were 26,226 housing units at an average density of 1,382.6 per square mile (533.8/kmÂ²), of which 19,529 (76.8%) were owner-occupied, and 5,903 (23.2%) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 1.3%; the rental vacancy rate was 3.7%. 68,924 people (75.2% of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 21,487 people (23.4%) lived in rental housing units. ===2000=== As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 89,730 people, 24,648 households, and 20,236 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 4,762.2 inhabitants per square mile (1,838.9/kmÂ²). There were 25,337 housing units at an average density of 1,344.7 per square mile (519.2/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of the city was 25.69% [[Race (United States Census)|White]], 25.41% [[Race (United States Census)|Black]] or [[Race (United States Census)|African American]], 0.56% [[Race (United States Census)|Native American]], 22.27% [[Race (United States Census)|Asian]], 2.99% [[Race (United States Census)|Pacific Islander]], 17.98% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 5.09% from two or more races. 34.92% of the population were [[Hispanics in the United States|Hispanic]] or [[Race (United States Census)|Latino]] of any race. There were 24,648 households out of which 39.2% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 58.7% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 17.2% had a female householder with no husband present, and 17.9% were non-families. 14.2% of all households were made up of individuals and 5.9% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.59 and the average family size was 3.92. Age ranges of residents were 28.4% under the age of 18, 9.9% from 18 to 24, 28.5% from 25 to 44, 22.5% from 45 to 64, and 10.7% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 34 years. For every 100 females there were 93.3 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 89.4 males. According to a 2006 estimate, the median income for a household in the city was $60,457, and the median income for a family was $66,468.[http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/ACSSAFFFacts?_event=Search&geo_id=16000US0608954&_geoContext=01000US%7C04000US06%7C16000US0608954&_street=&_county=carson&_cityTown=carson&_state=04000US06&_zip=&_lang=en&_sse=on&ActiveGeoDiv=geoSelect&_useEV=&pctxt=fph&pgsl=160&_submenuId=factsheet_1&ds_name=ACS_2006_SAFF&_ci_nbr=null&qr_name=null®=null%3Anull&_keyword=&_industry= http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/ACSSAFFFacts?_event=Search&geo_id=16000US0608954&_geoContext=01000US%7C04000US06%7C16000US0608954&_street=&_county=carson&_cityTown=carson&_state=04000US06&_zip=&_lang=en&_sse=on&ActiveGeoDiv=geoSelect&_useEV=&pctxt=fph&pgsl=160&_submenuId=factsheet_1&ds_name=ACS_2006_SAFF&_ci_nbr=null&qr_name=null®=null%3Anull&_keyword=&_industry=] ''factfinder.census.gov'' Males had a median income of $33,579 versus $31,110 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $17,107. About 7.2% of families and 9.3% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 10.9% of those under age 18 and 8.6% of those age 65 or over. Carson has the distinction of being the only incorporated city in the United States where the African American population has a higher median income than the Caucasian population.{{cite web | url = http://www.epodunk.com/cgi-bin/incomeOverview.php?locIndex=9966 | title = Carson - Income | accessdate = 2007-05-07}} ==Government and infrastructure== ===Local government=== According to the cityâs most recent Comprehensive Annual Financial Report, the cityâs various funds had $96.3 million in Revenues, $81.8 million in expenditures, $611.4 million in total assets, $129.2 million in total liabilities, and $187.2 million in cash and investments.[http://ci.carson.ca.us/content/files/pdfs/finance/cafr2006/CAFR2006_Basicfinancial_3.pdf City of Carson CAFR] Retrieved 2009-08-18 ===County, state, and federal representation=== Fire protection in Carson is provided by the [[Los Angeles County Fire Department]] which operates out of Fire Stations 10, 36, 116, 127, and 105.{{cite web|title=Battalion 7|url=http://fire.lacounty.gov/HometownFireStations/HometownFireStations.asp#Battalion07|work=Hometown Fire Stations|publisher=Los Angeles County Fire Department}} Ambulance transportation is provided by McCormick Ambulance Service Station 17.[http://www.mccormickambulance.com/stations.html McCormick Ambulance Service Station Locations] The [[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]] (LASD) operates the Carson Station in Carson."[http://www.lasd.org/stations/for2/carson/index.html Carson Station]." [[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]]. Retrieved on January 21, 2010. The [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]] operates the Torrance Health Center in [[Harbor Gateway, Los Angeles, California|Harbor Gateway]], [[Los Angeles]], near [[Torrance, California|Torrance]] and serving Carson."[http://publichealth.lacounty.gov/phn/docs/HealthCenter/torrance.pdf Torrance Health Center]." [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]]. Retrieved on March 18, 2010. In the [[California State Legislature|state legislature]] Carson is located in the 28th [[California State Senate|Senate]] District, represented by Democrat [[Ted Lieu]], and in the 55th [[California State Assembly|Assembly]] District, represented by Democrat [[Warren Furutani|Warren T. Furutani]]. Federally, Carson is located in [[California's 37th congressional district]], which has a [[Cook Partisan Voting Index|Cook PVI]] of D +27{{cite web | title = Will Gerrymandered Districts Stem the Wave of Voter Unrest? | publisher = Campaign Legal Center Blog | url=http://www.clcblog.org/blog_item-85.html | accessdate = 2008-02-10}} and is represented by Democrat [[Laura Richardson]]. The [[United States Postal Service]] operates the Carson Post Office at 21350 Avalon Boulevard and the South Bay Pavilion Station in Suite 116 at 20700 Avalon Boulevard."[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/4273?p=1&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=carson Post Office Location - CARSON]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008."[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/76198?p=2&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=carson Post Office Location - SOUTHBAY PAVILION STATION]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008. === Education === ==== Primary and secondary schools ==== Public schools are part of the [[Los Angeles Unified School District]]. They are: * 232nd Place Elementary School, * Catskill Elementary School * Carson Street Elementary School * Caroldale Learning Community * Del Amo Elementary School * Dolores Elementary School * Dominguez Elementary School * Andrew Carnegie Middle School * Stephen M. White Middle School * Broadacres Elementary * Leapwood Avenue Elementary School * Annalee Avenue Elementary School * Curtiss Middle School * Ambler Avenue Elementary School * Towne Avenue Elementary School High schools serving portions of Carson include [[Carson High School (Carson, California)|Carson High School]] and [[Banning High School (Los Angeles, California)|Banning High School]]. The area is within Board District 8.[http://www.lausd.k12.ca.us/lausd/board/secretary/BoardDistrictMaps/2007-08%20Board%20District%207.pdf Board District 7 Map]. ''[[Los Angeles Unified School District]]''. Retrieved on November 24, 2008. As of 2008 Dr. Richard Vladovic represents the district."[http://www.lausd.k12.ca.us/lausd/board/secretary/ Board Members]." ''[[Los Angeles Unified School District]]''. Retrieved on November 24, 2008. Some portions of Carson are in the [[Compton Unified School District]]. Although the [[California Academy of Mathematics and Science]] is located in Carson, it is actually a part of the [[Long Beach Unified School District]]. The school accepts residents of LBUSD, Compton USD, portions of LAUSD (including sections serving Carson), and other districts. === Public libraries === [[County of Los Angeles Public Library]] operates the Carson Regional Library and the Dr. Martin Luther King Library. Both libraries are in Carson. === Transportation === [[File:Current Carson Circuit Bus.jpg|thumb|Current Carson Circuit Bus]] The city operates the [[Carson Circuit Transit System|Carson Circuit]] [http://ci.carson.ca.us/content/department/dev_service/carson_circuit.asp] bus that serves the local community and connects to other bus services and the [[Del Amo (Los Angeles Metro station)|Del Amo Station]], as well as the North-South Shuttle [http://ci.carson.ca.us/content/department/dev_service/ns_shuttle.asp] which connects Carson to the [[Artesia Transit Center]]. == Sports == {| class="wikitable" |- ! scope="col" | Club ! scope="col" | League ! scope="col" | Venue ! scope="col" | Established ! scope="col" | Championships |- ! scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;" | [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] | [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] Soccer | [[The Home Depot Center]] | 1995 | 3 |- ! scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;" | [[Chivas USA]] | [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] Soccer | [[The Home Depot Center]] | 2004 | 0 |- |} == Attractions == [[File:BirdsinCarson.jpg|thumb|left|250px|A kind of small birds native to California resting on a tree in Carson, California.]] Carson is the site of [[California State University, Dominguez Hills]] (CSUDH). CSUDH is a major commuter school, particularly for African-American students from the surrounding cities of [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]], [[Gardena, California|Gardena]], and [[Compton, California|Compton]]. It was established in the wake of the 1965 [[Watts, Los Angeles, California|Watts]] riots, as a response to community outcry over the lack of higher education opportunities in the largely black south suburbs of Los Angeles. Today it is among the most racially diverse campuses in the United States. Prior to expansion in the mid 1960s, the university was located in nearby Palos Verdes. In 1965, Carson was chosen as the home for the relocating university over the communities of Friendship Park, Fort MacArthur and Torrance.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} Carson is also home to the Home Depot Center which is the home of the Los Angeles Galaxy soccer team and hosts the yearly JP Morgan/Chase tennis tournament. [[File:CSU Dominguez Hills.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[California State University, Dominguez Hills]] (CSUDH) campus.]] Carson is also the location of the [[Home Depot Center]], a sports complex including a [[soccer-specific stadium]] used by the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]], the Los Angeles Sol, and as of 2005, [[Chivas USA]], a tennis stadium and a track and field facility. It is also the default home ground for the [[United States men's national soccer team]]. It opened in 2003, adjacent to CSUDH. The ADT Event Center is the only permanent indoor [[velodrome]] in the U.S. In July 2007, the Galaxy signed international [[football (soccer)|soccer]] superstar [[David Beckham]] to the team. The [[Goodyear Blimp]] also has a landing pad in Carson, a fitting tribute to the 1st and 2nd U.S. and International Aviation Meets held at the Dominguez Hill Rancho in 1910 and 1911, which featured many [[blimp]]s and [[zeppelin]]s. The [[International Printing Museum]], which has one of the largest collections of antique printing presses in the United States, is located in Carson. == Economy == === Oil history === 1921 marked the first drilling for oil at Dominguez Hill, on the northwest side of the Dominguez Rancho, site of the famous battle during the [[Mexican-American War]] called the [[Battle of Dominguez Rancho]] in 1846. The mineral rights to this property were owned by Carson Estate Company, the Hellman Family, the Dominguez Estate Company, and the Burnham Exploration Company of [[Frederick Russell Burnham]]. On September 7, 1923, Burnham Exploration partnering with Union Oil brings in the first producer on the site: Callender No. 1-A well at a depth of {{convert|4068|ft|m}} and {{convert|1193|oilbbl/d}}.{{cite web |url=http://sites.google.com/site/petroleumhistoryresources/Home/this-week-in-petroleum-history |title=This Week In Petroleum History |author=Bruce A. Wells |date=September 16, 2010 |publisher=The American Oil & Gas Historical Society |accessdate=October 6, 2010}} It wasn't long before a number of refineries were up and running, with over 350 oil derricks, tank farms, and sprawling industrial complexes becoming a familiar part of the scenery. The principal leases were with [[Shell Oil Company]] and [[Union Oil of California]] and the first two wells were located west of Central Avenue and north of Victoria Street. Oil led to an increase in jobs in the community and a subsequent post-war population surge. An average of {{convert|300|oilbbl/d}} was produced from these wells through 1960. In 2011, Shell was ordered by the [[Los Angeles Regional Water Quality Control Board]] to clean up the Carousel neighborhood after [[benzene]] and [[methane]] gas contamination was discovered, as well as soil and groundwater contamination.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2011/03/shell-oil-ordered-to-clean-up-contaminated-carson-neighborhood.html|title=Shell Oil ordered to clean up contaminated Carson neighborhood | L.A. NOW | Los Angeles Times|last=Esquivel|first=Paloma|date=16 March 2011|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=16 March 2011}} ===Top employers=== According to the City's 2009 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report,[http://ci.carson.ca.us/content/files/pdfs/finance/cafr2009/CAFR2008-09_Statistics.pdf City of Carson CAFR] the top employers in the city are: {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |- ! # ! Employer ! # of Employees |- | 1 |[[BP]] West Coast |1,207 |- |2 |[[Northrop Grumman]] |1,126 |- |3 |Golden Wheel |899 |- |4 |Lakeshore Learning Materials |765 |- |5 |[[See's Candies]] |522 |- |6 |[[Target Corporation|Target]] |518 |- |7 |[[Leiner Health Products]] |440 |- |8 |[[PepsiCo|Pepsi Beverages Company]] |408 |- |9 |[[AT&T]] |388 |- |10 |[[Canon (company)|Canon Business Solutions]] |130 |- |} Other companies based in Carson include [[Ducommun]]. ==Shopping== Carson is home to the [[Pavilion at South Bay]] [[shopping mall]], located at the [[Avalon Boulevard]] exit off the [[Interstate 405 (California)|San Diego Freeway]] ([[Interstate 405 (California)|Interstate 405]]). Tenant stores include [[Sears]], [[Ikea]], [[Target Stores|Target]], and [[24 Hour Fitness]]. An outdoor [[Power center (retail)|power center]]/[[entertainment]] complex called [[Carson Marketplace]] has been planned but is not yet built. It is on a site once proposed for a stadium that could have played host to a [[National Football League]] team (see ''[[History of National Football League in Los Angeles]]'' for details). Construction has been delayed by the need for an extensive [[Environmental mitigation|environmental cleanup]], as this was once a [[toxic waste]] [[landfill|dump]]. == Notable residents == {{Unreferenced section|date=November 2009}} * [[Forest Whitaker]], director, producer, and Academy Awardâwinning actor * [[Juanita Millender-McDonald]], Democratic U.S. Congresswoman from 1996â2007 * [[Brandy Norwood|Brandy]], singer/actress * [[Ray J]] (Willie Norwood, Jr.), singer/actor * [[Ras Kass]], rapper * [[The Regulators]], Rock Group * [[Boo-Yaa T.R.I.B.E.]], Rap Group * [[The Game (rapper)|The Game]] (Jayceon Taylor), rapper. Lived in Carson from the ages of 7 to 15 while in foster care * [[Tommy "Tiny" Lister]], actor and former professional wrestler * [[Kia Stevens]], also known as Awesome Kong and Amazing Kong in [[TNA Wrestling]] - a professional wrestler * [[Chad Brown (American football official)|Chad Brown]], National Football League Umpire * [[Bishop Lamont]], rapper * [[Dr. Dre]] (Andre Young, Sr.), rapper/producer. Lived in Carson during his middle school years * [[Ekene Ibekwe]], University of Maryland forward * [[Tammy Townsend]], television actress * [[Chuckii Booker]], singer, songwriter * [[The Boys (band)|The Boys]], late 1980s R&B quartet * [[Courtney Hall]], former San Diego Chargers Center & Guard 1989â1999 * [[SoShy]], ( Deborah Epstein ), a French singer and songwriter. * [[Elbert Watts]], former Green Bay Packers Defensive Back 1986 == Movies/TV shows filmed in Carson == * [[24 (TV series)|24]] (Used [[CSUDH]] but was referenced on the show as [[UCSB]]) * [[Reno 911!]] [http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0370194/locations] * [[Reno 911!: Miami]] * [[The Social Network]] (Used [[CSUDH]]'s Ballroom) * [[Jackie Brown (film)]] [http://www.movie-locations.com/movies/j/jackiebrown.html] * [[Gone in 60 Seconds (1974 film)|Gone in 60 Seconds]] * [[Emergency!]] (Station 127 of the [[Los Angeles County Fire Department]]) * [[Evolution (film)|Evolution]] * [[Joe Dirt]] * [[Pros vs Joes]] * [[10 Items or Less (film)|10 Items or Less]] * [[The Cable Guy]] * [[Certified Gangstas]] (2004) Music video from rapper, [[Jim Jones (rapper)|Jim Jones]] * [[Colors (film)|Colors]] * [[Welcome Home, Roxy Carmichael]] ([[Winona Ryder]], [[Jeff Daniels]]) * [[Vega$]] (portions of TV show) * [[Gwen Stefani]]'s "[[Hollaback Girl]]" Video (S.M. White Middle School Drill & Carson Flaggies) * [[Hey Mickey]] [[music video]] (Carson High Cheer) * [[Entourage (TV series)|Entourage]] (Season 4 Episode 6 Card Convention at the Carson Community Center) ==See also== * [[Carson Community Center]] * [[List of California public officials charged with crimes#Carson|List of California public officials charged with crimes, Carson]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Los Angeles|Greater Los Angeles|Southern California}} * [http://ci.carson.ca.us/ Carson official website] * [http://lacdcs.com/station-end-page-16.html LA County Disaster Communication Service (DCS) Carson Sheriff Station] {{Cities of Los Angeles County, California}} {{Greater Los Angeles Area}} [[Category:Cities in Los Angeles County, California]] [[Category:Incorporated cities and towns in California]] [[Category:Populated places in the United States with Hispanic plurality populations]] [[Category:Populated places established in 1968]] [[ar:ÙØ§Ø±Ø³ÙÙ (ÙØ§ÙÙÙÙØ±ÙÙØ§)]] [[bg:ÐÐ°ÑÑÑÐ½ (ÐÐ°Ð»Ð¸ÑÐ¾ÑÐ½Ð¸Ñ)]] [[ca:Carson (CalifÃ²rnia)]] [[cs:Carson]] [[cy:Carson, California]] [[de:Carson (Kalifornien)]] [[es:Carson (California)]] [[eo:Carson (Kalifornio)]] [[fr:Carson (Californie)]] [[it:Carson (California)]] [[sw:Carson, California]] [[ht:Carson, KalifÃ²ni]] [[nl:Carson (CaliforniÃ«)]] [[pnb:Ú©Ø§Ø±Ø³Ù]] [[pl:Carson (Kalifornia)]] [[pt:Carson (CalifÃ³rnia)]] [[ru:ÐÐ°ÑÑÐ¾Ð½ (ÐÐ°Ð»Ð¸ÑÐ¾ÑÐ½Ð¸Ñ)]] [[sr:ÐÐ°ÑÑÐ¾Ð½]] [[fi:Carson (Kalifornia)]] [[sv:Carson, Kalifornien]] [[tl:Lungsod ng Carson, Kaliporniya]] [[vi:Carson, California]] [[vo:Carson (California)]]
